comment_text.dn33:1.1.2: This discourse picks up from DN 29:17.1, where the Buddha urges that the Sangha should gather and recite the Dhamma for the long lasting of the dispensation. There he lists the 37 factors of awakening, a standard early collation of practice-oriented teachings that are primarily collected in the Mahāvagga of the Saṁyutta Nikāya. This discourse is a late one, and appears to be an initial attempt to compile a more thorough list of the Buddha’s teachings. The Sarvāstivāda version of the same discourse formed the basis of one of their seven Abhidhamma books, the Sangītiparyāya.
comment_text.dn33:1.1.3: At AN 10.176 Cunda asks about the purity of the western brahmins; at DN 16:4.13.5 = Ud 8.5 he offers the Buddha’s last meal; at Snp 1.5 he asks about a true ascetic.
comment_text.dn33:1.2.1: The completion of a town hall was celebrated by a talk for the Sakyans SN 35.243:1.2 and MN 53:2.1. Such halls were community meeting places that played a central role in civic society and communal decision-making in democratic republics such as the Mallas and the Sakyans. The Buddha’s participation is a sign of his support for their civic and democratic process.
comment_text.dn33:1.4.5: As at DN 16:5.19.2, the Mallas are called Vāseṭṭhas after the family lineage of their priest (purohita).
comment_text.dn33:1.5.5: The Buddha likewise mentions his bad back and invites another monk to teach in both the other suttas where he is first to teach in a new hall (MN 53:5.3, SN 35.243:3.4), and also on the uposatha at Naḷakapāna (AN 10.67, AN 10.68). These were all occasions when the community was sitting late into the night.
comment_text.dn33:1.6.1: As at DN 29:1.3 and MN 104:2.1, in both of which the Buddha was in the Sakyan lands at this time. There, the news is conveyed to the Buddha by the novice Cunda. Perhaps he was confused with Cunda the smith.
comment_text.dn33:1.7.10: Sāriputta adopts the “Aṅguttara principle” of arranging teachings by number rather than the “Saṁyutta principle” of arrangement by topic. Thus this list of teachings has more in common with the Aṅguttara Nikāya than with the Buddha’s original list of Saṁyutta topics. I note unusual or rare terms, but the references here are meant to be indicative rather than comprehensive.
comment_text.dn33:1.8.2: AN 10.27:10.5, AN 10.28:4.5, Kp 4:1.2. | Compare Bṛhadāranyaka Upaniṣad 5.12.1, “for all these beings are contained in food”, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.11.9, “all these beings live when they partake of food”, Taittirīya Upaniṣad 2.2.1, “any creatures who dwell on earth are produced from food, and by food alone they live.”
comment_text.dn33:1.8.3: This phrase is unique, but here saṅkhārā (“conditions”) is a synonym of āhāra (“food, fuel, nutriment”).
comment_text.dn33:1.8.4: The paucity of teachings of “one” reflects the fact that the Aṅguttara Nikāya Ones consists mostly of longer teachings that have been split into atoms to artificially create “ones”.
comment_text.dn33:1.9.27: Samathanimitta at SN 46.2:14.2 and SN 46.51:11.2; paggahanimitta at AN 3.102.
comment_text.dn33:1.9.36: “Knowledge of ending” (khaye ñāṇaṁ) refers to the aggregates; it is discussed at SN 12.23. | “Knowledge of non-arising” (anuppāde ñāṇaṁ) is the knowledge that one will not be born again.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.53: At AN 4.33:2.2 cessation is the middle, not an extreme. But SN 22.103 has four extremes.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.59: The “right way” is the eightfold path, the “wrong way” the opposite (SN 45.21). “Surety in the right way” is mentioned often (eg. AN 5.151), although I normally render it “sure path”. “Surety in the wrong way” seems to be found only in later texts. “Lack of surety” is impermanence. And elsewhere these are not said to be “heaps”.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.61: Despite the explanation, and the prevalence of reading kaṅkhā, the commentary requires the Mahāsaṅgīti reading tama.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.74: AN 7.47:12.3. | For dakkhiṇeyyaggi, compare Sanskrit dakṣiṇāgni, a fire sacrifice for ancestors established in a hearth to the south.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.76: Elsewhere found only in Abhidhamma. “Visible and resistant” refers to material phenomena perceivable by the eye. “Invisible and resistant” is a shorthand for material phenomena that are not perceivable by the eye, but which nonetheless impinge on other senses, such as sounds or smells. “Invisible and non-resistant” includes form perceived solely in the mind (Vb 3:49.2).
comment_text.dn33:1.10.80: The last item is elsewhere found only in Abhidhamma texts. A “trainee” is a noble one who has at least entered the path to stream-entry; an “adept” (asekkha) has completed their training; one who is neither is yet to begin.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.103: The first is unique, the next two from AN 5.170.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.107: Otherwise found only in Abhidhamma and other late texts.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.109: The “weapon of learning” is at AN 7.67:17.3, the “weapon of wisdom” in verse at Dhp 40:3 and Thag 16.3:17.3.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.111: Found at SN 48.23:1.3 and Iti 62:2.3, this went on to become a standard Abhidhamma set.
comment_text.dn33:1.10.121: This threefold presentation of the process of absorption focuses on vitakka (“placing the mind”) and vicāra (“keeping it connected”), looking closely at how they cease (see also DN 34:1.4.7, MN 128:31.4, SN 43.3:1.2, and AN 8.63:3.1). The standard jhāna formula focuses more on the refinement of feelings, from which perspective the first two stages of immersion here fall under the “rapture and bliss born of seclusion”, while only the third qualifies as “rapture and bliss born of immersion”. Thus Analayo describes the two descriptions' as “complementary perspectives on the same process of deepening concentration” (Comparative Study, vol. ii, pg. 739, note 263).
comment_text.dn33:1.10.129: AN 6.79:1.3; explained at Vb 16:259.1. These passages, and Thag 2.19:2.1, are the earliest appearances of the phrase “skill in means” (upāyakosalla) that would become famous in later Buddhism.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.55: These are described as “limitless” in the formula, but this is the only early text they are called the “four limitless states” (or “immeasurables”). This is a sign of systematization.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.60: Often described as “formless”, here is the only place we find “four formless states” (āruppā).
comment_text.dn33:1.11.71: AN 4.28. The sequence of pahāna (“giving up”) and bhāvanā (“meditation”) is swapped as compared with AN 4.28:4.1.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.103: “Knowledge of the teaching” is the understanding of the observable principles of the teaching. | “Inferential knowledge” applies that to the past and future, especially in understanding the minds and behaviors of others without reading their minds. | “Knowledge of encompassing” is the psychic ability to read or “encompass” the mind of another. | “Conventional knowledge” is explained as understanding that is not included in the former three (Vb 16:310.1). It would especially include Vinaya matters that are agreed on “by convention” (AN 8.90:1.2, DN 33:1.10.82). | The first two are found at SN 12.33:14.2; see notes there for further discussion. The four are found at DN 34:1.5.3 and Vb 16:307.1.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.115: This discourse distinguishes the “factors of a stream-enterer” (sotāpannassa aṅgāni) from the “factors of stream-entry” (sotāpattiyaṅgāni), but elsewhere only the latter term is used SN 12.42:3.1, AN 9.28:4.1.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.156: By treating ethical decisions via a tetralemma, the Buddha rejects the “law of the excluded middle” and the consequent belief that acts must be either right or wrong.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.162: AN 4.189, but the order there is direct experience, recollection, vision, wisdom.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.174: MN 12:32.1. The four describe the births of different kinds of nāga (SN 29.1) and phoenix (SN 30.1).
comment_text.dn33:1.11.193: This and the next are found in AN 4.250, etc., but there defined, as below, in terms of speech about what you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known.
comment_text.dn33:1.11.209: AN 4.198. | “With self become divine” (brahmabhūtena attanā) deliberately echoes Upaniṣadic language. Pali is sometimes said to lack reference to the cosmic Brahman (in neuter), having only the personal Brahmā (in masculine). The grammatical case of brahma- in the compound here is undetermined, yet no scholar of Sanskrit would hesitate to interpret the common phrase brahmabhūtātmā in the sense “self become one with the cosmic divinity Brahman”. Surely the Pali draws from the same sense, using it to describe Nibbāna.
comment_text.dn33:2.1.5: For the distinction between “aggregates” and “grasping aggregates” see SN 22.48, SN 22.82, MN 109.
comment_text.dn33:2.1.15: Also at MN 12:35.3. Later the asura (“demon” or “titan”) realm was added as the sixth. The number and nature of different realms is always somewhat fluid.
comment_text.dn33:2.1.140: These five are found at AN 5.72 and AN 5.305, and also as part of longer lists. They are not, however, called “perceptions that ripen in freedom”.
comment_text.dn33:2.2.21: As “roots of arguments” at AN 6.36:1.5 and MN 104:6.5 (see below), and as impossibilities for a stream-enterer at AN 6.92.
comment_text.dn33:2.2.23: As a cause for the long lasting of the dispensation at AN 6.40:2.2.
comment_text.dn33:2.2.30: At AN 3.61:12.1 and MN 140:10.1 these three sets of six are combined as the “eighteen mental preoccupations”.
comment_text.dn33:2.2.126: In AN 6.57 this is a response to the doctrine of Pūraṇa Kassapa.
comment_text.dn33:2.2.128: At AN 6.142 and AN 6.35, but not called “perceptions that help penetration”.
comment_text.dn33:2.3.5: Ariyadhana appears to be constructed after ācariyadhana, “a teacher’s fee”, and hence ariya here would be a noun rather than verb.
comment_text.dn33:2.3.15: At AN 7.68 dhamma in this context is shown to be “teachings”, not “qualities”.
comment_text.dn33:2.3.50: Primarily a Vinaya topic (Kd 14:14.16.1), but also found at AN 7.84 and explained at MN 104:13.1.
comment_text.dn33:3.1.95: These are just called “gifts” at AN 8.31. The “reasons to give” at AN 8.33 are different.
comment_text.dn33:3.1.103: “Settled for less” also occurs at AN 8.35:1.9. Readings vary between hīne vimuttaṁ (“released in what is inferior”, per MS) and hīne ’dhimuttaṁ (“resolved upon what is inferior”). This is an example of an ambiguity between vi + √muc (“release”) and adhi + √muc (“resolve”) that is sometimes seen in Pali texts. The subcommentary reads vimuttaṁ and offers two explanations: “‘Released’ (vimuttaṁ) means ‘resolved’ (adhimuttaṁ); the meaning is slants, slopes, and inclines. Or else ‘released’ means ‘set free’ (vissaṭṭhaṁ).” Given that it is clearly accepted in the commentarial tradition, and that it is the more difficult reading, it seems we must accept vimuttaṁ as the correct reading here. But from context, and from the subcommentary, it has the same sense as adhimutta, namely, “resolved upon”. This goes some way to explaining the ambiguity between the two words, as they not only have a similar form, but their meanings can overlap too.
comment_text.dn33:3.1.108: Notice that they have “seen” the well-to-do brahmins or aristocrats, but have only “heard of” the various deities.
comment_text.dn33:3.1.136: Previous rebirths required only ethics. Rebirth in the Brahmā realm, however, requires the freedom of the mind from hindrances through practicing absorption.
comment_text.dn33:3.2.60: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.3.10 warns that, because the knowledge of the gods have not reached them, the lands beyond the borders are the domain of death.
comment_text.dn33:3.2.71: Eight at AN 8.29 and DN 34:2.1.122; the ninth here is made by adding the asura rebirth.
comment_text.dn33:3.2.91: Also at AN 9.31 and AN 9.61. Compare the “progressive cessation of conditions” at SN 36.11.
comment_text.dn33:3.3.29: The pre-Buddhist sense of sati is “memory”, while “mindfulness” evolved from the practice of “remembering” scripture, creating an uninterrupted flow state in the present. In this sense, mindfulness can be understood as the element of continuity that knits consciousness together in a coherent stream. Thus when practicing “mindfulness of breathing” one pays continuous attention to the breaths, not “forgetting” what one is doing.
comment_text.dn33:3.3.45: AN 10.25. Kaṣina means “universal”, “totality”, and it refers to a measureless state of jhāna. In later usage it became a term for a physical object, such as a disk, on which a meditator focused, but it never has this meaning in early texts. Yājñavalkya says that, just as salt is “entirely” salty, the Self is an “entire mass of consciousness” (kṛtsnaḥ prajñānaghana eva, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.5.13).

root_text.dn33:1.1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā mallesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena pāvā nāma mallānaṁ nagaraṁ tadavasari.
root_text.dn33:1.1.3: Tatra sudaṁ bhagavā pāvāyaṁ viharati cundassa kammāraputtassa ambavane.
root_text.dn33:1.2.1: Tena kho pana samayena pāveyyakānaṁ mallānaṁ ubbhatakaṁ nāma navaṁ sandhāgāraṁ acirakāritaṁ hoti anajjhāvuṭṭhaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenaci vā manussabhūtena.
root_text.dn33:1.2.2: Assosuṁ kho pāveyyakā mallā: “bhagavā kira mallesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi pāvaṁ anuppatto pāvāyaṁ viharati cundassa kammāraputtassa ambavane”ti.
root_text.dn33:1.2.3: Atha kho pāveyyakā mallā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho pāveyyakā mallā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn33:1.2.4: “idha, bhante, pāveyyakānaṁ mallānaṁ ubbhatakaṁ nāma navaṁ sandhāgāraṁ acirakāritaṁ hoti anajjhāvuṭṭhaṁ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenaci vā manussabhūtena.
root_text.dn33:1.2.5: Tañca kho, bhante, bhagavā paṭhamaṁ paribhuñjatu, bhagavatā paṭhamaṁ paribhuttaṁ pacchā pāveyyakā mallā paribhuñjissanti.
root_text.dn33:1.2.6: Tadassa pāveyyakānaṁ mallānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
root_text.dn33:1.3.1: Atha kho pāveyyakā mallā bhagavato adhivāsanaṁ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā yena sandhāgāraṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā sabbasanthariṁ sandhāgāraṁ santharitvā bhagavato āsanāni paññāpetvā udakamaṇikaṁ patiṭṭhapetvā telapadīpaṁ āropetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu;
root_text.dn33:1.3.3: Ekamantaṁ ṭhitā kho te pāveyyakā mallā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn33:1.3.4: “sabbasantharisanthataṁ, bhante, sandhāgāraṁ, bhagavato āsanāni paññattāni, udakamaṇiko patiṭṭhāpito, telapadīpo āropito.
root_text.dn33:1.4.1: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena yena sandhāgāraṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā pāde pakkhāletvā sandhāgāraṁ pavisitvā majjhimaṁ thambhaṁ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisīdi.
root_text.dn33:1.4.2: Bhikkhusaṅghopi kho pāde pakkhāletvā sandhāgāraṁ pavisitvā pacchimaṁ bhittiṁ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisīdi bhagavantaṁyeva purakkhatvā.
root_text.dn33:1.4.3: Pāveyyakāpi kho mallā pāde pakkhāletvā sandhāgāraṁ pavisitvā puratthimaṁ bhittiṁ nissāya pacchimābhimukhā nisīdiṁsu bhagavantaṁyeva purakkhatvā.
root_text.dn33:1.4.4: Atha kho bhagavā pāveyyake malle bahudeva rattiṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṁsetvā uyyojesi:
root_text.dn33:1.4.7: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho pāveyyakā mallā bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkamiṁsu.
root_text.dn33:1.5.1: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantesu pāveyyakesu mallesu tuṇhībhūtaṁ tuṇhībhūtaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ anuviloketvā āyasmantaṁ sāriputtaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn33:1.5.6: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.dn33:1.5.7: Atha kho bhagavā catugguṇaṁ saṅghāṭiṁ paññāpetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṁ kappesi pāde pādaṁ accādhāya, sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṁ manasi karitvā.
root_text.dn33:1.6.1: Tena kho pana samayena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto pāvāyaṁ adhunākālaṅkato hoti.
root_text.dn33:1.6.2: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
root_text.dn33:1.6.3: “na tvaṁ imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ ājānāsi, ahaṁ imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ ājānāmi, kiṁ tvaṁ imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ ājānissasi. Micchāpaṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammāpaṭipanno. Sahitaṁ me, asahitaṁ te. Purevacanīyaṁ pacchā avaca, pacchāvacanīyaṁ pure avaca. Adhiciṇṇaṁ te viparāvattaṁ, āropito te vādo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vādappamokkhāya, nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosī”ti.
root_text.dn33:1.6.4: Vadhoyeva kho maññe nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu vattati.
root_text.dn33:1.6.5: Yepi nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā, tepi nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu nibbinnarūpā virattarūpā paṭivānarūpā, yathā taṁ durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṁvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe.
root_text.dn33:1.7.1: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.dn33:1.7.3: tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā …pe… bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe.
root_text.dn33:1.7.4: Evañhetaṁ, āvuso, hoti durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṁvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite.
root_text.dn33:1.7.5: Ayaṁ kho panāvuso, amhākaṁ bhagavatā dhammo svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṁvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito.
root_text.dn33:1.7.6: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṁ, na vivaditabbaṁ, yathayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ addhaniyaṁ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṁ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.

root_text.dn33:1.11.5: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.dn33:1.11.8: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.dn33:1.11.10: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.

root_text.dn33:1.11.13: Uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.20: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.21: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.22: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.23: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.

root_text.dn33:1.11.34: Katamā cāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ñāṇadassanapaṭilābhāya saṁvattati?
root_text.dn33:1.11.35: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu ālokasaññaṁ manasi karoti, divāsaññaṁ adhiṭṭhāti yathā divā tathā rattiṁ, yathā rattiṁ tathā divā.

root_text.dn33:1.11.38: Katamā cāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṁvattati?

root_text.dn33:1.11.42: Ayaṁ, āvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṁvattati.

root_text.dn33:1.11.52: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.55: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.57: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.58: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.59: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.60: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.62: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṁ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṁ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṁ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṁ vinodeti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.64: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca cīvarahetu anesanaṁ appatirūpaṁ āpajjati; aladdhā ca cīvaraṁ na paritassati, laddhā ca cīvaraṁ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati; tāya ca pana itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṁseti na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.65: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato, ayaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṁse ṭhito’.
root_text.dn33:1.11.66: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, itarītarapiṇḍapātasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca piṇḍapātahetu anesanaṁ appatirūpaṁ āpajjati; aladdhā ca piṇḍapātaṁ na paritassati, laddhā ca piṇḍapātaṁ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati; tāya ca pana itarītarapiṇḍapātasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṁseti na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.67: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato, ayaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṁse ṭhito’.
root_text.dn33:1.11.68: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, itarītarasenāsanasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca senāsanahetu anesanaṁ appatirūpaṁ āpajjati; aladdhā ca senāsanaṁ na paritassati, laddhā ca senāsanaṁ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati; tāya ca pana itarītarasenāsanasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṁseti na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.69: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato, ayaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṁse ṭhito’.
root_text.dn33:1.11.70: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu pahānārāmo hoti pahānarato, bhāvanārāmo hoti bhāvanārato; tāya ca pana pahānārāmatāya pahānaratiyā bhāvanārāmatāya bhāvanāratiyā nevattānukkaṁseti na paraṁ vambheti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.71: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato ayaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṁse ṭhito’.
root_text.dn33:1.11.75: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.dn33:1.11.76: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.81: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.dn33:1.11.82: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.dn33:1.11.85: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṁ kāmavitakkaṁ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantiṁ karoti anabhāvaṁ gameti;
root_text.dn33:1.11.88: uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantiṁ karoti anabhāvaṁ gameti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.91: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ,
root_text.dn33:1.11.97: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṁ bhāveti vivekanissitaṁ virāganissitaṁ nirodhanissitaṁ vossaggapariṇāmiṁ.
root_text.dn33:1.11.100: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu uppannaṁ bhadrakaṁ samādhinimittaṁ anurakkhati—aṭṭhikasaññaṁ, puḷuvakasaññaṁ, vinīlakasaññaṁ, vicchiddakasaññaṁ, uddhumātakasaññaṁ.

root_text.dn33:1.11.109: Idhāvuso, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti:
root_text.dn33:1.11.110: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho, bhagavā’ti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.112: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.114: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho yadidaṁ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā, esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassā’ti.
root_text.dn33:1.11.115: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi acchiddehi asabalehi akammāsehi bhujissehi viññuppasatthehi aparāmaṭṭhehi samādhisaṁvattanikehi.

translation_text.dn33:1.1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Mallas together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a Mallian town named Pāvā.
translation_text.dn33:1.1.3: There he stayed in Cunda the smith’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn33:1.2.1: Now at that time a new town hall named Ubbhaṭaka had recently been constructed for the Mallas of Pāvā. It had not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any human at all.
translation_text.dn33:1.2.2: The Mallas of Pāvā also heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in Cunda’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn33:1.2.3: Then they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.dn33:1.2.4: “Sir, a new town hall named Ubbhaṭaka has recently been constructed for the Mallas of Pāvā. It has not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any human at all.
translation_text.dn33:1.2.5: May the Buddha be the first to use it, and only then will the Mallas of Pāvā use it.
translation_text.dn33:1.2.6: That would be for the lasting welfare and happiness of the Mallas of Pāvā.”
translation_text.dn33:1.3.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, the Mallas got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the new town hall, where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed an oil lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn33:1.3.3: and told him of their preparations, saying,
translation_text.dn33:1.4.1: Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the new town hall together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. Having washed his feet he entered the town hall and sat against the central column facing east.
translation_text.dn33:1.4.2: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.
translation_text.dn33:1.4.3: The Mallas of Pāvā also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.
translation_text.dn33:1.4.4: The Buddha spent much of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the Mallas with a Dhamma talk. Then he sent them off,
translation_text.dn33:1.4.7: “Yes, sir,” replied the Mallas. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

translation_text.dn33:1.5.2: “Sāriputta, the Saṅgha of mendicants is rid of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.dn33:1.5.3: Give them some Dhamma talk as you feel inspired.
translation_text.dn33:1.5.7: And then the Buddha spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
translation_text.dn33:1.6.1: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had recently passed away at Pāvā.
translation_text.dn33:1.6.2: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
translation_text.dn33:1.6.3: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
translation_text.dn33:1.6.4: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.
translation_text.dn33:1.6.5: And the Jain Ñātika’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.
translation_text.dn33:1.7.1: Then Sāriputta told the mendicants about these things. He went on to say,
translation_text.dn33:1.7.4: “That’s what happens, reverends, when a teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn33:1.7.5: But this teaching is well explained and well propounded to us by the Blessed One, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.dn33:1.7.6: You should all recite this in concert, without disputing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

translation_text.dn33:2.1.47: Five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics:
translation_text.dn33:2.1.48: Firstly, an ethical person gains great wealth on account of diligence.
translation_text.dn33:2.1.50: Furthermore, an ethical person gets a good reputation.
translation_text.dn33:2.1.52: Furthermore, an ethical person enters any kind of assembly bold and self-assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.
translation_text.dn33:2.1.54: Furthermore, an ethical person dies not feeling lost.
translation_text.dn33:2.1.56: Furthermore, when an ethical person’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

translation_text.dn33:2.1.128: Firstly, the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant.

translation_text.dn33:3.1.26: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.28: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. But while walking my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.29: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn33:3.1.30: This is the fourth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.31: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.33: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is tired and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.34: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn33:3.1.35: This is the fifth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.36: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.38: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is heavy and unfit for work, like I’ve just eaten a load of beans. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.39: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn33:3.1.40: This is the sixth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.41: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.43: ‘I feel a little sick. Lying down would be good for me. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.45: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy…
translation_text.dn33:3.1.46: This is the seventh ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.47: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.49: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. My body is weak and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.50: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.51: This is the eighth ground for laziness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.53: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.55: ‘I have some work to do. While working it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.56: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.57: This is the first ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.58: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.60: ‘I’ve done some work. While I was working I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.62: This is the second ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.63: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.65: ‘I have to go on a journey. While walking it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.68: This is the third ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.69: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.71: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. While I was walking I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.73: This is the fourth ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.74: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.76: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is light and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.78: This is the fifth ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.79: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.81: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is strong and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.83: This is the sixth ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.84: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.86: ‘I feel a little sick. It’s possible this illness will worsen. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.88: This is the seventh ground for arousing energy.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.89: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.91: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. It’s possible the illness will come back. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.92: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.93: This is the eighth ground for arousing energy.

It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’ Or they give thinking, ‘By giving this gift I’ll get a good reputation.’ Or they give thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.98: First, someone gives to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.99: Whatever they give they expect back.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.100: They see an affluent aristocrat or brahmin or householder amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.102: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders!’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.103: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it. As they’ve settled for less and not developed further, their thought leads to rebirth there.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.104: But I say that this is only for those of ethical conduct, not for the unethical.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.105: The heart’s wish of an ethical person succeeds because of their purity.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.106: Next, someone gives to ascetics or brahmins.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.107: Whatever they give they expect back.

translation_text.dn33:3.1.124: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others!’

translation_text.dn33:3.1.133: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the Divinity’s host!’

translation_text.dn33:3.1.136: And for those free of desire, not those with desire.

translation_text.dn33:3.1.139: the assemblies of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics. An assembly of the gods of the four great kings. An assembly of the gods of the thirty-three. An assembly of Māras. An assembly of divinities.

translation_text.dn33:3.1.143: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.144: This is the first dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.145: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.147: This is the second dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.148: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.149: This is the third dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.150: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.151: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.152: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.153: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.154: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.155: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.156: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.157: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.158: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.159: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.160: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.161: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.162: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.163: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.164: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.165: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.166: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
translation_text.dn33:3.1.167: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.169: Having physical form, they see forms.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.171: Not perceiving physical form internally, they see forms externally.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.175: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.177: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.179: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.181: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.183: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.185: These are the teachings grouped by eight that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.
translation_text.dn33:3.1.186: You should all recite these in concert.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.1: There are teachings grouped by nine that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.2: You should all recite these in concert.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.3: What are the teachings grouped by nine?

translation_text.dn33:3.2.19: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love …’ …
translation_text.dn33:3.2.20: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love …’ …

translation_text.dn33:3.2.25: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.26: This is the first abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.27: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.28: This is the second abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.29: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.30: This is the third abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.31: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.32: This is the fourth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.33: There are sentient beings that are non-percipient and do not experience anything, such as the gods who are non-percipient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.34: This is the fifth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.35: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.36: This is the sixth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.37: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.38: This is the seventh abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.39: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.40: This is the eighth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.41: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. They have been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.42: This is the ninth abode of sentient beings.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.44: Firstly, a Realized One has arisen in the world. He teaches the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.45: But that individual has been reborn in hell.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.46: This is the first lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.47: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.48: But that individual has been reborn in the animal realm.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.49: This is the second lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.50: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.51: But an individual has been reborn in the ghost realm.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.52: This is the third lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.53: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.54: But that individual has been reborn among the titans.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.55: This is the fourth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.56: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.57: But that individual has been reborn in one of the long-lived orders of gods.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.58: This is the fifth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.59: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.60: But that individual has been reborn in the borderlands, among uneducated foreigners, where monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen do not go.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.61: This is the sixth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.62: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.63: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they have wrong view and distorted perspective:
translation_text.dn33:3.2.64: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
translation_text.dn33:3.2.65: This is the seventh lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.66: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.67: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they’re witless, dull, idiotic, and unable to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.68: This is the eighth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.69: Furthermore, no Realized One has arisen in the world,
translation_text.dn33:3.2.70: so there is no teaching of the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One. But an individual is reborn in a central country. And they’re wise, bright, clever, and able to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.71: This is the ninth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.73: A mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.74: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.75: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.dn33:3.2.76: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.77: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.78: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.79: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.80: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.81: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.83: For someone who has attained the first absorption, sensual perceptions have ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.84: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.85: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.86: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.87: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.88: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.89: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.90: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.91: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.92: These are the teachings grouped by nine that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.
translation_text.dn33:3.2.93: You should all recite these in concert.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.1: There are teachings grouped by ten that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.2: You should all recite these in concert.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.3: What are the teachings grouped by ten?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.5: Firstly, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.7: This is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.8: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.10: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.11: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.13: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.14: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.16: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.17: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.19: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.20: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.22: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.23: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.25: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.26: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.28: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.29: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.31: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.32: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.34: This too is a quality that serves as protector.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.36: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.37: They perceive the meditation on universal water …
translation_text.dn33:3.3.45: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.47: killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.49: refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; refraining from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.51: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.52: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.53: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.54: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.55: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.56: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.57: Hearing a sound with their ears … Smelling an odor with their nose … Tasting a flavor with their tongue … Feeling a touch with their body …
translation_text.dn33:3.3.58: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.59: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.60: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.61: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.62: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.63: And how does a mendicant have four supports?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.64: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.65: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.66: And how has a mendicant cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.67: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. A mendicant has cast out, cast aside, thrown out, discarded, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.68: That’s how a mendicant has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.69: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.70: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.71: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.72: And how does a mendicant have unsullied intentions?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.73: It’s when they’ve given up sensual, malicious, and cruel intentions.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.74: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.75: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.76: It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.77: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.78: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.79: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.80: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.81: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?
translation_text.dn33:3.3.82: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’
translation_text.dn33:3.3.85: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.87: an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.88: Reverends, these are the teachings grouped by ten that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.
translation_text.dn33:3.3.89: You should all recite these in concert, without disputing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
translation_text.dn33:3.4.1: Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Sāriputta,
translation_text.dn33:3.4.3: It’s good that you’ve taught this exposition of the reciting in concert.”
translation_text.dn33:3.4.4: That is what Venerable Sāriputta said, and the teacher approved.
translation_text.dn33:3.4.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.
